thread.title: No. 16 Stanford benefitting from inexperienced opposing quarterbacks
thread.title_full: No. 16 Stanford benefitting from inexperienced opposing quarterbacks

author:
Jon Wilner

jwilner@mercurynews.com
title: No. 16 Stanford benefitting from inexperienced opposing quarterbacks
text:
If you're searching for signs that this is Stanford's year, look no further than the list of opposing quarterbacks the young Cardinal defense has faced -- and will continue to face. 
Six rookies in the first seven games: 
Week 1: Northwestern redshirt freshman Clayton Thorson. 
Week 2: UCF true freshman Bo Schneider, who replaced injured veteran Justin Holman midway through the first quarter. 
Week 4: Oregon State true freshman Seth Collins. 
Week 5: Arizona's seldom-used Jerrard Randall, who started in place of injured Anu Solomon. 
It's a gift from the football gods -- a gift that keeps on giving. 
The starting quarterback for Stanford's next opponent, UCLA, is also a true freshman: Josh Rosen. UCLA quarterback Josh Rosen (3) tosses a pass early in the first quarter against Arizona State at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., on Saturday, Oct. 3, 2015. Arizona State won, 38-23. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times/TNS) ( Robert Gauthier ) 
After that, it's Washington and yet another true freshman: Jake Browning. 
The lone veteran to face the rebuilt Cardinal secondary thus far: USC's Cody Kessler, who threw for 272 yards and three touchdowns. 
"You just have to show them what college football is about," Stanford linebacker Blake Martinez said of the rookies. 
Asked about Rosen specifically, he added: "We're not going to do anything crazy for him. We'll just go at what UCLA does on offense and make sure they don't get any explosive plays." 
And in case you were looking ahead, the lineup of quarterbacks set to face the Cardinal in the final month includes a redshirt freshman (Notre Dame), a sophomore (Washington State) and not Marcus Mariota (Oregon). Advertisement 
Speaking of Rosen: 
The Manhattan Beach product was the top-rated quarterback in the class of 2015, and Stanford stood atop his wish list. But according to reports, the Cardinal didn't offer a scholarship because of what it perceived to be Rosen's overbearing attitude. 
Coach David Shaw addressed the situation earlier this week: "It's just the recruiting process and all the crap that comes out. He's a great kid ... I don't have to rehash (the situation)." For more on college sports, see Jon Wilner's College Hotline at blogs.mercurynews.com/collegesports . Contact him at jwilner@mercurynews.com or 408-920-5716.
